content:
Open the OpenPGP Key Manager. Select the key to be exported. File - Export Public Key(s) To File

Alternatively, right-click a key - Export Public Key(s) To File
creator: christ1

content: Thank you Christ1 for the suggestion. I never would have guessed that the File menu would be acting as a contextual menu, as this does not conform to any UI standard. I don't know of any other program that uses the File menu as a contextual menu like this. This is horrible user interface design. The right-click contextual menu provides no option to export the private key. Instead, the right-click contextual menu has been broken into two parts, with the part of the right-click contextual menu that should allow exporting the private key actually appearing in the File menu instead. It's amazing that a user interface with so many users can be so poorly implemented. Just amazing.
creator: bugzillameow

content:
Let's try an easy approach first, as it may work. If your backup is a copy of the appdata\roaming\thunderbird folder, just copy that thunderbird folder to overlay the existing appdata\roaming\thunderbird folder with thunderbird NOT RUNNING, and restart thunderbird.

OK, if all you have is a backup of the profile, here's another, low-tech, approach. This is a bit clumsy, but I don't know your comfort zone. Do this. - Delete the appdata\roaming\thunderbird folder - download thunderbird again from thunderbird.net and reinstall it - start thunderbird, skip the option for new email address, and click help>troubleshootinginfformation - scroll down to 'profile folder' and click 'open folder' - EXIT thunderbird <== IMPORTANT - you are now in the profile. Copy your backup profile folder's contents and paste to overlay all content here - restart thunderbird
creator: davidsk

content: My guess is that thunderbird created a new profile and that the addressbook is there, but in another profile. My assumption is that Thunderbird was already installed and that you were updating to a newer version. Try this: - click help>troubleshootinginformation - scroll down to 'profiles' and click 'about:profiles' - if there is more than one profile showing, click 'open folder' on the inactive one - now, the addressbook's name is abook.sqlite. do you see one there, that may have been updated recently? If so, that may be your missing addressbook. If so, then copy the abook.sqlite and history.sqlite files to a separate folder (This is temporary) - now, close windows file manager and you are back in thunderbird at the list of profiles. Now, click 'open folder' for the active profile, then EXIT THUNDERBIRD, now, paste the two copied addressbooks here, overlaying the current files. - now, restart thunderbird and your addressbook should be there.
creator: davidsk

content:
You may want to talk to your email provider.

Also see https://support.mozilla.org/kb/cannot-send-messages
creator: christ1

content:
You have to have an existing email address with an email provider, e.g. Gmail, or Yahoo, etc. If you don't have an email address yet, create an account with the email provider of your choice.

Then, in Thunderbird set up your account: At the top right of the Thunderbird window, click the menu button ≡ > New Account > Email
creator: christ1

content:
I just tested to download the "Thunderbird.147.0.1.dmg" installer disk image with Firefox from the linked page. The download was very quick and at its end a popup window indicated that the download was terminated. At the same moment the https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/desktop/ web page switched to the donation screen and the Thunderbird.147.0.1.dmg icon appeared on my Desktop. Maybe at the end of the download you didn't notice that in the meantime the download action had taken place....?

My desktop is the "target folder" when I download files or folders using Firefox. I don't know to which directory you download files, but did you verify whether it contains the Thunderbird.147.0.1.dmg installer disk image?
creator: Mapenzi

content:
Per accedere alla posta già scaricata ti basta fare click su Annulla quando ti viene chiesta la password principale. Potrai leggere la vecchia posta ma non scaricare la nuova.

Per il reset della password principale c'è solo il metodo descritto qui https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/password-principale-thunderbird#w_reimpostare-una-password-principale-dimenticata-o-persa Se non riesci a portarlo a termine purtroppo non c'è altro che si possa fare.

Se non riesci nel reset puoi solo ripartire da un profilo Thunderbird pulito. Se i tuoi account email sono di tipo IMAP dovresti recuperare tutto direttamente alla prima connessione. Se sono POP3 dovresti comunque poter recuperare la vecchia posta dal profilo attuale; in questo secondo caso posso indicarti degli appunti per come procedere.
creator: @next

content:
La procedura di backup suggerita per Thunderbird consiste nel fare copia dell'intera cartella del profilo -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/profili-thunderbird#w_effettuare-una-copia-di-sicurezza-del-profilo

Se vuoi invece fare una copia solo dei messaggi (magari in formati più pratici come eml e pdf) puoi usare l'estensione ImportExportTools NG -> https://addons.thunderbird.net/it/thunderbird/addon/importexporttools-ng/
creator: @next

content:
Per poter inquadrare il problema prova a fornire queste informazioni:

  1. Versione di Thunderbird
  2. Versione del sistema operativo
  3. Provider delle caselle email (Gmail, Libero, Hotmail, etc.)
  4. Tipologia di account (POP3, IMAP)
  5. Estensioni installate
  6. Messaggi di errore che vengono visualizzati durante l'utilizzo di Thunderbird
  7. Software di sicurezza eventualmente presenti (Antivirus e simili)
  8. Screenshot del problema (se utile a chiarire il contesto)
creator: @next
